insects.name: Western Tiger Swallowtail
facts: Commonly found along rivers and in canyons.
Adults feed on nectar from flowers.

insects.name: California Sister
facts: Found in oak woodlands.
Feeds on oak tree sap.

insects.name: Common Green Darner
facts: Known for its bright green thorax.
Often seen in large swarms.

insects.name: Blue Dasher
facts: Has vibrant blue coloration.
Perches with its wings forward.

insects.name: Eastern Pondhawk
facts: Females are bright green, males are blue.
Commonly found near ponds and lakes.

insects.name: Halloween Pennant
facts: Named for its orange and black wings.
Often seen perched on grass stems.

insects.name: Twelve-Spotted Skimmer
facts: Recognizable by its twelve black spots on its wings.
Males have white spots between the black spots.

insects.name: Widow Skimmer
facts: Males have a distinctive white and black pattern.
Females are more subdued in coloration.

insects.name: Common Whitetail
facts: Males have a white body, females have a brown body.
Both sexes have dark bands on their wings.

insects.name: Black Saddlebags
facts: Named for the black patches on its wings.
Often seen gliding over ponds and marshes.

insects.name: Carolina Saddlebags
facts: Has red patches on its wings resembling saddlebags.
Commonly found in the southeastern United States.

insects.name: Eastern Amberwing
facts: Small dragonfly with amber-colored wings.
Often found near still or slow-moving water.

insects.name: Banded Pennant
facts: Has distinctive black bands on its wings.
Males and females look similar.

insects.name: Calico Pennant
facts: Known for its red or yellow spots on the wings.
Commonly found in meadows and fields.

insects.name: Four-Spotted Skimmer
facts: Has four distinct spots on its wings.
Found in both North America and Europe.

insects.name: Great Blue Skimmer
facts: One of the largest skimmers in North America.
Males have a powdery blue body.

insects.name: Painted Skimmer
facts: Wings have amber patches and brown stripes.
Commonly seen in spring and early summer.

insects.name: Roseate Skimmer
facts: Males are bright pink, females are brownish.
Found near ponds, lakes, and slow streams.

insects.name: Ruby Meadowhawk
facts: Males are bright red, females are yellowish.
Commonly found in meadows and fields.

insects.name: Autumn Meadowhawk
facts: Active late into the autumn.
Males are red, females are brownish.

insects.name: Blue Corporal
facts: Males are powdery blue, females are brown.
Often seen basking on the ground or on vegetation.

insects.name: Chalk-fronted Corporal
facts: Has chalky white front and black abdomen.
Commonly found in northern North America.

insects.name: Dot-tailed Whiteface
facts: Has a white face and a small yellow spot near the end of the abdomen.
Found in ponds, lakes, and bogs.

insects.name: Frosted Whiteface
facts: Has a frosted white face and black body.
Found in northern bogs and marshes.

insects.name: Hudsonian Whiteface
facts: Has a white face and black body with red spots.
Found in northern North America.

insects.name: Spangled Skimmer
facts: Males are blue, females are brown.
Has distinctive white and black spots on the wing tips.
